div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½
(£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from
the 1st or 16th of any month.

or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T.
10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for
standing advertisements.

to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.

We hope—though not with much coufi dence, for the misuhief makers sre tireless io their penitence—that the lost has been heard of the Natal ‘ atrocities” They prove* as might co: fidently have been foretold from the oatseh not to have been atrooities stall. and all tairminded Eugli-hmen will accept without hesitation the rfiidial statement of the Natal Government, which was read in the House of Commons yesterday by the Under¬secretary for the Colouiee. But they will do do more than this. They will reprobate in the strongest manner the disingenuous attitude of the Ministry towards these slanderous attacks 01 the charaoter of their owo kith and kin. Instead of xialom-ly defending the honour of a little Colony ,whioh has been threatened with a terrible danger, the British Government has elected to play the part of a cold, self righteous judge. We deplore - the effeot. which the discussion that followed mnst have, upon all men of British blood ' in South’ Africa, for what the Minister added, of his own initiates, cm only be nnderstood as implying official esnsare upon the coi- dnot of one of tbeufficers ol the Natal forces. For the most sensational act of barbarism asoribed to the troops under the oommand of Colonel Mnokei zie was the foatting off of the head of the arch rebel Bambaata. The sugges tion was that this was done for sheer wan- tODness, as a piece of ferccions savagery, worthy of the dead man himself. We were old that the head was sent round as a'sort of ghastly trophy, to intimidate the other chiefs into sarrguder. Nothing coaid be farther, from the troth. The ofiioial explanation is per- simple and honoarable.Bitubasta’s body at the bottom of a deep gorge, twothoasand feet below the oamp, and it was a matter of urgent importance that tbore t-bonld be no doubt as to his fate. Major Platt, of the Army Medical Corps, was sent with a native escort. He fonDd the body badly decomposed,and when the natives refaseid to cury it to camp, the head was ampnta’e I. it was kept under armed- escort in absolate Privacy ; it was only shown to those who- professed to know the chief, and when the identity was verified beyond qnee tion, it was retarnedto the spot where it htd been foand, and baried with the body. Wherein lies the atrooity What is there in this story which need inspire honor or disgust? T'hesnbjeot is an unpleasant one to dwell upon-like everyting connected with a post¬mortem—bnt there is absolutely not a shred of reaion why a British Minister should not have expressed his satisfaction that a fool slander had been so entirely disproved. That, however, is not the way of this Government iu dealing with the British Colonies. Their consistent attitude is to be willing to wound, yet afraid to strike. The Colonial Under S« cretaiy, when asked whether the Government had conveyed any comment on the the fcroat- ment'of Bambata’s body, made the amazing statement that he feated “the British Govern-ment were not in the.best position to act" as oensors. And then he went on to say that under the late Administrationthe Khalifa’s head had been “most shamefally treated and that he thought it obvious that “sneh. an evil precedent wooU be quoted against ns by the Colony in reply to any remonstrance we might think it necessary to make.* When Mr. Arnold Forster, very properly, pressed him to say whether he imputed any disgrace¬ful aot fo Major Platt, the only answer he could obtain was that the Under Secretary for the-Colonies did not think it ’ half so disgrace¬ful as the steps taken in regard to the Mahdi." Frank and open oensore would have been far preferable to this glancing suggestion of con¬demnation, whioh. will be hotly resented in Natal. Moreover,the attack on Lord kitchene was. as gratuitous as it was unwarranted. There is no need dr us to justify what was done in the Sondan after the fall of Omdur- man. On that oooasion, as in Natal, those in command of the troops took the measares they deemed . most efficacious for convincing tbsir beaten and fanatical enemies that further resistance was useless Then, as now, the sensation-mongers wereluiy with their lies. There were Exactly the same charges as to killing the wonnded. ft was boldly eaid that orders had been issued that no quarter should be given. Lord Kitchener was reviled by the tribe of unthinking sentimentalist! at horns, who hardly concealed their regrets that the British oasdal ties were so email in comparison with tbdsd of the Dervishes, and wrote of the Khalifa’s savage tribe men as though they were entitled to the favour and consideration dne to a civilised and hnmaue race. Massacre there has efen none, though the ghastly mutilations perpetrated upon the few white men who have fallen into the hands pf these Zola rebels would go far to condone any savage reprisals committed in the heat o f action. It is difficult, however, to write with patience of the-atrocity loving public at home, for which these stories are manufactured with unfailing regdlAfity as often as war is afoot No charge is-too outrageoos to find credence,i f only it be brought against their own coontry- men. It is nothing to them if english offi¬cers are stoned and beafeo. to death by the rabble, of an Egyptian village, but their con¬sciences are sorely hart if the morderers are panished. An English police inspector is stabbed through and through with assegais—it is a re¬grettable incident in the eyes of the English Ra¬dical. But when his slayers are tried by court- and fchot the Imperial Gjvernmoat must inter* vene. And if'the rebellion of a horde of blood¬thirsty Zuffir, who would massacre! every man and woman in Natal if once they got the upper hand, is rathlessly crashed under foot by a gallant little band of white men fighting under conditions of great hazard and difficulty, a clamour rises for inquiry, and a Radical 1 Ministry looks on with cold suspicion is' ready with protestations of horror, and grossly attaoks the most distinguished ioidier in the aotfve servioe of the Crown. This Pharisaical attitude of mind is bound to have deplorable results in the Colonies. the slauders pnblisbed here so freely are all sent back over the wires, and read with anger. And the anger is just It is an intolerable thing that in this bard crisis of her fortunes so gallant, so loyal, so public spirited colony as Natal whose sons are fighting in the field, should be slandered n the Press of the Mother Coontry, and find, not friendship, but harsh censorship, in the Brititsh Ministry. (From the “Daily Telegraph.")>

div.p: SITUATIoN iN EGYPT. HUMAN PLAGUE. OUR BERBEREEN. MOSLEM UNREST IN NORTH AFRICA. Trial Of Calinopoulo CaliCopoulo, who recently tortured his Greek female servant to death, will be brought before the Hellenio Consular Conrt in December next for trial Hashish seizures. At the beginning of the month the Coast Guards seized right camels laden with 295 kilos, aud on the 16th inst. nine camels laden with 602bilos of hashish,iu theWesteru Desert* Attempted Sulolde. A Turk living in the Custom house quarter attemptel to oommit snioide this morning by stabbing himself in the abdomen. He was removed to hospital in a precarious condition. Land Tax. The “Journal OUi del” publishes a table of the taxes assessed on land in the Assiont pro vince in accordance with the Khediyial deoree of the 10th May, 1899. The new rates will come into fo.roe on the 1st January 1907. Vlotlm of Railway Aooldant Wo regret to annoauoe the death of Hussein Bey Yawer, who sucoambed to his injuries received in the railway collision at Roubbeb last week. The funeral took place in the Arid cemetery on Wednesday.^ Flahlng Boat Disaster. -The Italian consular authorities have yet been unsuccessful in refloating the fishing boat which oapsized off the Abonkir coast last week, and the bodies of the uufortunate seamen who perished are still under water. Suspension of Consorlption. The PubHo Health Department has requested the War Offioe to suspend conscription opera- ' tions io the provinces of Ghirgeh, Minieb, and Beni Sonet for fifteen days owing to the appearauoe ot bubonic plague in those pro* vinces. Interesting to Utdlos. We would call attention to an advertisement which appears in another column of the annual oheap stook taking sale now being carried on at “An De Rouge,” Cairo—an establishment so well noted for its reasonable prices, that any redaction far the purpose of stock-taking should not be missed by its customers, to whom Mr. Plankett always gives credit for the enlargement of his premises. CUM dl toor.to s dl Rlsparmlo. Mr. George Bennett, who has been acting manager of the Cairo branch of the above bank, has now been appointed manager of the branch, Meiers. Giuseppe Martinelli and James H. Coatsworth, fondds des poavoirs at the Alex¬andria head office, have been appointed sub¬managers here. M. Nicoles stefanacbi,\^ondd des ponvoirs at the Cairo branch, has been appointed sub-manager of that branch, and M. 8.D. Mandil foDdd des ponvoirs of the same branch. Continental Hotel The military band which plays every Wed¬nesday evening on the terraria of the G and Continental Hutel, Cairo, during dinner and afterwards until 11 o’olock, is proving a con¬siderable attraotiou. Last Wednesday night eevetal’Cairo residents- dined there, and the terraoe was also crowded with others who did not dine. An excellent menu was provided and the programme of music, which was played by the etying baud of the 2nd Inniskil'.ing Fusi¬liers, was well varied and most enj?yable. Whole Family Poisoned. s Last Monday morning, says our Minet el Kamh Correspondent, all the members of a family at BI Walaga, in the Minet el Kamh ’ Marksz, suddenly became very ill with the exception of one. It was suspected that somebody had placed poison in their* supper me»l, and the result of. the investigations of the local authorities confirmed this belief. The victims are now well on the road to recovery, owing to prompt medical aid, but come arrests are Jikply to be made. » St Jamas's Restaurant. MaDy improvements have been made in the St James’s ReetanVant ainoe it was taken over by M. Marknrg, late of Shepheard’a Hotel, one of the latest of which is the adlitidn of an open-air restaurant, in front of the hotel. M. Marburg has bedn granted permission to ap¬propriate a portion of the broad pavement, and this he has surrounded with trellis work upon which creepers are being grown. The innovation is greatly weloomed by the many patrons of this popular restaurant, who are now able to dine in the open air and yet enjoy the privacy of the inside restaurant. Duel In Cairo. MILITARY ASPECTJDISf'USSED. SLATIN PASHA’S VIEWS. LOYALTY OF EGYPTIAN ARMY. ( Gaxotto's Special Service,) LONDON, Friday, July £7. At a meeting of the Committee of Imperial Defeboe, held yesterday, it is understood that the military aspect of the situation in Egypt was under review. Advantage was taken of Lord Cromer’s presence in Lohdou tozhear his per¬sonal views on the matter, /flir Reginald Wingate, the Sirdar, was alsd brought into consultation by the committee. The 3rd Battalion of the Coldstream Qaards is embarking for Egypt at the end of September. In the course ot an interview with a repre¬sentative of the “Nene Froie Prease” of Vienna, Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha said that he did het believe aDy serious danger was imminent, but Great Britain must show that she has the will and the power to maintain her position in Egypt, and the British garrison must be in¬creased. ‘ • Questioned as to the condition of the Egypt¬ian Army, Slatin Pasha said there war not the slightest ground to doubt the loyalty of the officers and men. KHEDIVE AND ARMY. The following message was received by the Officer commanding the British Troops iu reply to a congratulatory telegram sent to his Highness the Khedive, oa the occasion of his birthday (23rd inst.) . “I am directed by his Highness the Khedive to express to you and all ranks of the British Forces in Egyp\ his sincere thanks for your kind message of congratulation on the occasion of his Birthday. —Graud Master of Ceremonies.” SUQRERIES RAILWAY. We understand that the railway lines belong¬ing to the Socidtd des Sncreries et de la Raffi- nerie de I’Egypte have been sold to the Govern¬ment for LB. 400/00. The act of transfer was signed on Saturday by Abaui Pasha, for the Government, and Harari Pasha, for the company. EOYl CENSUS OF EGYPT. “A1 Mokattam” states that the Connoil of Ministers approved at its last meeting a note by the' Ministry of Finance proposing an 'exhaustive census of the population in Egypt, to oommeuoe frpm the beginning of-nixt year. As the census will require a large army of agents—hot les? than eighty thousand—and the^ expenditure of large sums of money, the notr proposed to charge all Government em¬ployes to assist in it. A dietriot will be assigned to each employe which he will be required to go through between snnBet and midnight daily until-be* has completed his task. The Council of Ministers have oommnnica ted their decision to all Ministries and Govern¬ment Adnjnistraiions, requesting them at the same time fc) a>k their respective staffs residing Cairo to sentftheir names and addresses to the Ceusns Depvrtment, those residing at Alexandria to the Municipal authorities of the town, and those residing elsewhere to the administrative authorities in whose distriota they reside BENHA BRIDGE. The new swing.arch which has been bnilt to support the extra weight to which Beuha Bridge is being subjected, has jaat been tried, but with what resalt is not yet known. This construction is the first ot a series of works to carried ont on the whole span of the bridge, which, built originally for locomotives of £0 tons, has now to bear the strain of 35 tons extra iu the new looomotives. It is expected that the bridge will he tho¬roughly renovated within eighteen months hence, until when the trains will cross at a slow speed. Ji'he interesting feature of these new works is that they are'being carried oat without hindrance to the regular traffic. SjAN STEFANO CASINO. The following in the meno of the dinner to IWW IT IS-CONTRACTED WORST FORM OF THE DISEASE. Ii comparison with 1904 there was a con¬siderable diminution in the number of oases of plague in Egypt last year, says the report of thp Public Health Department. The number of/cnes brought to their notice dariug 19n5 amounted to 266. of whiob 181 termioatedh with fatal results, the. remainder recovering; in IdO1 the number of oases amount¬ed to 855, with 501 deaths. Many of the towns of Egypt in which there was a serious outbreak of Jhe disease during 1904 remained entirely free from it daring 1905. The town in which the largest number of cases occurred daring 1905 was Alexandria, hjch famished 127 cases with 87 deaths, twenty-five of these, with six'deaths, occurring among Europea fas and the remainder among the native population. Only two eases were reported in towns south of Cairo. „ . Plague has persisted io Alexandria each year since 1899,, when the first cases were discovered here* It is the only town in which a system of drainage exists, and many of the drains are in a very dilapidated oondition and infested with rats; this may be one* of the reasons which account for the persistence of the disease at Alexandria, as .from the ex¬perience.gained by the department they find that the infected rat is the oause of the disease remaining endemic in a town, but the epidejnie form of the disease is caused by theiufeoted human being. There seems no donbt that the disease in the simple bnbonio form is frequently contrac¬ted by human beings trom rats either by handling'thie rat itself or becoming infected by the,ficcal matter or nrine from an iufeoted rat. These simple, bubonic cases may go on to suppuration and ultimate recovery without* causing any farther spread of the disease, bat some of these simple cases develop the disease in the septiemmio or pneumonic form, when they become highly dangerous and oapable of disseminating the disease among all persons approaching them. For this reason it is of the greatest importance to isolate all oases of simple bnbonio plague as it is impossible to foresee whether this or that case will not develop the more dangerous form of the disease, and in the event of it doing so the necessary, precautions in an isolation hospital oa^be taken to prevent it spreading the disease to others. In some of the towns ot Upper Egypt where we have not had any notification of the disease before, one pr two pneumonic cases have occur¬red *’ continues the report, “the disease has rapidly spretd among the inmates of the -house where the case Ins ^occurred and among the neighbours who have visited the ease or atten¬ded the funerals ; in some cases whole families have b?en wiped ont by the disease in a few days. There is no donbt that in many instances in these villages a simple bubonic case has oooarred which has not been notified, and having developed a more serious aud infectious form of the disease hab been the cause of spreading it in an epidemio form ; in other instances a case of septica?mio plague has escaped from an infected village and carried the disease to some neighbouring villages. “In no towns where cases of simple bubonic plague have been detected at the commence ment, and precautionary measures taken at once, has the disease taken on an epidemic form. “ plague, as is well known, was endemic in Egypt op to 1815. Statistics showing the num¬ber of deaths notified as dne to plague in Alexandria monthly from the years 1834 to 1843 being available, Lhave thought it would be of interest to reprint these in order that they might be oompared with the rnonthly mortality of the disease in Alexandria from 1899 to 1905. “From 1834 cf P43 it is reasonable to sup¬pose that very few praotioal measures were taken to keep the disease under oontrol; from 1899 to 1905 every effort has been made to isolate all cases ocoarring, and prevent the spread cf the disease. ‘The population of Alexandria and its suburbs must be little short of 380,000 at prarcut,whereas during the’thirties and ’forties of the last century it probably did not reach the fifth of this ; the general hygienio oondition of the town, however, is far superior to what it was ic the early part of the last century and the inhabitants in a more prosperous oondition and better able to withstand an epidemio disease such as plague. DISGRACEFUL ASSAULT IN CAIRO* A Cairo contemporary publishes the follow¬ing remarkable story, whiob we reprodnoe in extepeo. It seemB that the Capital requires to be oleate I of unemployed aud unemployable Barabra even more than Alexandria, and we shonld like to suggest to the Cairo polioe authorities that the sooner these useless aud ill-eouditioued oreatares are removed the bet¬ter for public ordor and quiet The following is the story, which we repro duos with the necessary reserves, but which is, iu ourj opinion, only, too likely to. be well fouhdda :—• “In Atfet es Soug, a lane between the Coptic Bazaar and C|ot Bey-street, there is a hashish den managed by a native, who has had fre¬quent disputes with the polioe and has been several times charged with the same contraven¬tion, bat Done the less oontinaes to carry on his scandalous occupation. It is true that the ghaffirs and polioe of the quarter do not disdain to pay oooasiopal visits to the den and ^njoy a few whiffs of1 the poison that is so dear to the native. In^iAnwquenoo these good people fra¬ternise and lend one another mutual aid and protection when required, as was proved on Tnesday, fa propos of an inorease of the rent whi/rf?the proprietor of the ofafd wished to im¬post on his tenant, who had to pay or qnit The tenant (and manager of the den) accepted neither solation and decided to give his land¬lord a good drubbing.- On Taesday eveniug, at about 11 o’clock, the native, aided by four or five Barabra who lived in the din, attacked the landlord—»n old Earopean of 65 years of age,—palled him down,«and satisfied their ill-temper by kioking him. iKfaawish who was present followed the various phases of the drama without moving a muscle. The Berbereen then handed the Euro¬pean over to the ghaffir, who beat him lnstily with a nabont. A Frenchman who was passing made enqui¬ries into the cause of the attaok, but being unable to obtain any explanations, and not knowing who was in the right, contented him¬self with taking the nombers of the extraordi¬nary shawish and the brutal ghaffir. The for¬mer bore the No. 1131, the latter the No. 7. This action on the part of the Frenchman was taken very ill by the pair. They laid hands on him and showed a wish to t^re him the oaraool. He protested most energetically and the onlprits, seeing that thing* might tarn out badly for them, did their best to appease this inconvenient witness by the ready “ma- leesh.” Silence and order being restored, shawish atSlr ghaffir rejoined their friends by the hashistrden, and while they talked with the Berbereen who had beaten the old Earopean rthey Were heard to laugh and congratulate /themselvei on having given $ sound thrashing, npt to an inconvenient landlord—Oh no ! — but to a * kelb Nastini.” . ^BAID ON HASHISH DENS, y Several sheds were recentlj^erected on a Unoooupied plot of land^ between the Cairo station and the rae Olali by some iugenioas individuals who thought they saw a chance of opening hashish dens without the necessity of explaining matters to landlords and of evading the vigilanoe of the polioe. Large orowds assembled night after night as one shed after another was.erected, aud the respeotable inha¬bitants of the quarter were losing patience and being condemned to listen nigh 1 after night to the howls and shouts of a crowd of low-olass Arabs, when on Wednesday night the police descended apon the plaoe, drove off the orowd, demolishing the sheds, and seized the hashish. The state of filth in which the hashish smokers and other vagabonds have left the looality requires the attention of the Depart¬ment of Pub’io Health. • PERSONAL AND SOCIAL MENACE TO FRENCH INTERESTS. Ahmed Bey'Zaki, second secretary to the Connoil of Mt^isters, is replaoirg Cotta Bey. the first secretary, who left a few days ago on ordinaiy leave for Europe. Dr. Harold Nolan, medical adviser to the Mixed Tribunals, leaves for Earope on the 1 st prox. Ferid' Ifey Babatoghlu, of the Ministry Pablio Wonts, who composed a French'’poem commemorating the marriage of H. M. the King of Spain, has received a letter of thanks from Connt de Andeno, His Majesty's private rmwetary, infotming him that the King has conferred on him the rank of Commander the Order of Isabel The- ^Miais.try of Justice has appointed Younis Raslan Eff., moawin of Maghagha Markaz, as Proseentor to the Parqnet before the Markriz Tribunal Sir Edward^Grey’s solemn warning as to the revival of fanaticism in Egypt and North Africa continues to be one of the main topics of con¬versation in Paris, aooording to the correspon¬dent of the “Times,” and the details given by Lord Cromer in the Parliamentary paper on the Tabah incident have served to bring home to French opinion the fact that the utterances of Sir Edward Grey were no mere matter of Parliamentary strategy. . The “Temps” has received a letter from Binder, the small negtfo Saltanate whiob by the reoent delimitation of French and English terri¬tories has now become a French possession, showing that France, too, will be wise to take the Mussulman agitation serionsly. Sinder is the link between the French territories of the Sudan and of the Chad, and is the terminus of the only caravan road between the Sudan and Tripoli. In the snrronnding region certain deplorable events have recently ooenrred ; three British officers have been killed in Sokoto, two French officers have met with the same fate at Niamey, and thore is some agitation in the Kanem district These events have exoited fanatical feeling Sinder, with the result that a plot was oon- oooted in which the teligions element played the leading rule, and in which took part the Saltan, Malem Yaro, the rich Tripoli merchant well known to travellers in the Sudan, the interpreter of the French authorities, a neigh¬bouring chief, and various leading men. There a French garrison at Sinder, but it was mnch depleted, the oommander even being absent on toor of inspection, circumstances by which the conspirators sought to profit in order to massacre the rest of the troops. The coup was take place early in April. The plot was discovered and thwarted. At the moment of writing the conspirators were in prison and the officer in command only awaited the return of his chief to pass jadgment on thfam. The ‘‘Temj^s,” comfaaenting or. this incident, says that mnch vigilanoe’ is required in con¬nexion with the schemes attributed to the Tripolitan Tarks. It is still being annoanoed that they are preparing to oooapy Janet and Bilma. The “Temps” thinks that the prudent French policy would be to forestall this action by plaoing French garrisons at those pointfc. We're Turkish troops to put in their appearance at Bi'ma the ccnsequenoes would be oarriedfar and wide along the Sudan 680 border. . M. Engfane Lantier, writing in the “Figaro,” says that the most important part of the English Parliamentary paper j st issued is that referring to the growth of ffavatioism in Egypt. Had thfa^onflicji between Turkey and England assumed a more serious form the Turkish troops would, it was said, 'have" menaced the Suez Canal and advanced as far as Nekhl, an import¬ant strategic position. It was therefore dear that Turkey had reck ined upon a rising of the Egyptian Nationalists, and doubtless had reasons for doing so. In M. Lantier’s opinion one of Lord Cromeris letters shows that Sir Edward Grey had been guilty of no exaggera¬tion in speaking of the precautions which had to be taken in Egypt The High Commissioner refuted the charges of the Egyptian Opposition as to the neglect of moral progress and educa tion, adding that it was necessary to reinforce the British garrison. M. Lantier adds:— If I understand him rightly, Lord Cromer considers that it is desirable to show considera¬tion and to take no hasiy action, at least until the Britisfi garrison in Egypt is stronger. The situation is therefore a very serious one. The British Government has doubtless issued the Parliamentary paper in order to enlighten pnblic opinion on the sabjeot. The docaments on the Tabah incident are bat the prefaoe. The gist of the publication is to be foofad in Lord Cromer’s letters. ... It is to be hoped that a few simple-minded Frenchmen will not allow themselves to be take a in by the declamation of certain Egyptians whose propaganda supplements that of German agents in Cairo and elsewhere. Our cause is that of England, and we ooght to take advan tage of Lord Cromer’s warnings. It is now obvions that if war had been deolared last year we and those who would have wished to help ns wonld have had to reokon with a gene¬ral revolt of our Musiulman suhj >ct9. . . . For that reason all French sympathy with Egyptian nationalism is positive madness. In case of a general contliot the members of that party would be a tramp in the hands of Onr adversaries.” Situation “Exiremely Sorloua^ “The situation is extremely serious. Oar attention is attracted to it on the same grounds as those of oar neighbours across the Channel, British and French interests being equally ifi perilled. To such a formidable common enemy as tha preient one it is "desirable to oppose the Diplomatic entente of the two European Powers who alone rule over Mahomedan sbb jeots.” This is the praotioal conclusion drawn by the from “Ganlois” what it desoribes as the prospect of a Mussnlman rising. It regards the Tabah inoident as a timely warning of the serions eventuality with which British, and even Fiench, interesteare menaced North Africa—namely, a reorndescence fanaticism among the Mobamedans of Egypt, Tripoli, and the Sudan. “For the past 12 months/’ the “Ganlois” oon- which finds expression daily in partial reyoltfl against- Europeans and s ticks upon fiiitinb d French officers. . . . The Tabah incident, provoked by the Forte, WJS oply a pretext favour thjs Mohomedau agitation. Turkey hoped that the appearance of a Turkish foroe the Soez* Canal would lead to an ootbarst of fanaticism iu * Egypt J . But it is pot in Egypt alone that this relkioos fanaticism is being manifested, which ^Turkish polioy has¬tens to exploit for its own^advantage It is gradually extending to all West Africa. must not be imagined that this agitation wRl disappear or lestriot itself to certain localities ofjts own acoord. As a matter of fact, its origin is associated with the Moroc¬can qnestioo. The German Emperor^in going to Tangier, declared that he went to the as-sistance of the Mossolmans. Since then the latter heye not ceased to reoeixe encourage¬ment from German agents, who, under pretest o^xplorations, pursue and develop in Africa the vast ambitions of William II/ The “Liberld” dwells upon the necessity that France should dxeroise dose vigilance upon all her ‘ Arab frontiers.” Attaoks- are, it says, directed against the French and British ocou- pation, and, in view of the uncjrtainty as to the origin and extent cf this reaction, it is ' essential to arsume a vigorous defensive. Si-multaneously with the inoident at Sinder—a region in which two French officers were recently killed, while three British officers were massacred at Sokoto-an. unforeseen complication has aricen on the Tripoli fron-tier. This is the rnmonr th at a Turkish co¬lumn has undertaken polioing operations within the French sphere of influence. An- then tic details, are not yet to hand respecting thi’a fresh inoident, bat letters from the soath of Tunis do not permit any doubt as totheir- reality. This attempted Turkish encroachment aocording to the same journal, but .a re¬petition of the patrols—and, indeed, raids— by Redjeb Pat ha * on the southern frontier of Tonis,, which had necessitated an inter¬vention of the French troops. Bnt, adds the “Liberty,” what is still more serious is the oonviotion of all the residents and officers in the extreme south that a deliberate plan, prepared in Europe, is ready to be pot into exeention. It concludes by urging the adop¬tion of measures of praotioal pro den oe on the French African froatier, together with a vigo¬rous protest at Constantinople, as a means of averting this serions Menace. The Loaaon of 7,t The “Sifaole,” commenting upon the reoent British Parliamentary paper on. Egypt, draws “the lesson of .Tabah.” The advanoe of the Tarkibh troops to Tabah was, it says, an attempt of the greatest gravity, indmating as it did the tendenoy prevailing at Yild'z Kiosk, inot only with regard tb Egypt, bat\lso towards the other European Powers ruling ov)Brv Mussulman subjects. “It was bound to 'be regarded as sm encouragement to the/Tan- Islamib propaganda, of which there" had been previous indications and which has been greatly favoured for several years past, Aether intentionally or otherwise, by the Ottoman polioy of William II. If England had tolerated this encroachment upon the admi¬nistration of Egypt by Ahdal Hamid, the Saltan would have secured a victory pregnant with immediate oomequanoee. It was to he expeoted that the Turkish pretensions would soon give rise to storins throoghon-t the whole Mussnlman world. Inpresenoe of the relations known to exist between the German Emperor, and Abdul Hamid it could no. -be supposed for an instant that the latUr had aoted with¬out the approval or, fodeed^ the advice of the_^ former. Therefore WUliaip' II. soaght some^ •iptext for a general conflagration. .... The Tabah incident has opened Lord Cromer’s eyes to the importance of the Pan: Islamio movement in the valley of the Nile and to the necessity of reinforcing the Anglo- Egyptian garrisons in saoh a way ■ as to reoder them capable of resisting all menaoes either from abroad, like that of Akabah, or in the country itself in consequence of Pan-Islamic agitation.” Referring to the letter addressed to Lord Cromer by an Egyptian stating that in case of a straggle between ' England and Turkey all his oonntrymen would side with the Saltan, who incarnates the Mussulman faith, this Berioas organ ot enlightened French opinion considers that this statement truly represents the feeling of ths nominal subjects of the Khedive. It adds that the Government in London will not tail to profit by Lord Cromer’s advice.>

div.p:
contract Onr company .had during this pe riod held their hands as regards new bosj i oss, and were prejudiced by tho action taken. Considerable fueling was aroused among the shareholders in Egypt, and it is nnder stood that a member of the Delta London board was specially sent 'to Egypt in connec tion with the fasion of the companies. Ad vances were subseqaently again made to ns, and another preliminary agreement was en tered into on the basis of six. to one. This is the agreement now brought before tho general meeting. The shares to be given to XJS were to* be part of.tjieir authorised re serve of 50,000 shares. / After the second agreement WAS signed the board of this oom pany ascertained that tha Delta Lands Lon don board had in their circular asking con formation of the second agreement also asked their shareholders ta inoreaae their oapital from £250,000 to £'>00,00% or, ip other words, to. double it'Their action appeared to m de¬nsity affect the value of the ' shares they had agreed to give for our assets, and the scatter was, therefore, specially brought to the attention of our shareholders and of the Delta board. In their reply to our rem in strance the Delta board states:—(I) That only power to make sach increase WAS being sought; (9) that such increase was to bo made as and when and if required ; and (3) that the immediate issue of any part of it was so doab fill that the price of issue had not even been consiffere/,' and they farther stater! t|iat if tha occasion arore for issaiog, oar share¬holders were likely to receive cmsiddrable benefit trom a pro rata distribution of new shares. The board of thia’ company are advised by experts well acquainted with Egyptian business thd the mere decision to increase, the capital will be enough to start a selling movement, and that the proposals about the inore>se of capital prej idi oially atfectel the valne of the shares. It is clear that, if their oapital be increased as they propose, the holders ought to be prepared within the specifiel limits to find tin additional oapital wh ch tho Ddta bnrd may from time consider they neet To keep our shares eqni valent to their valae any new issue would have to be at least over £ 1 10s per £ I share. D o our ahareho’ders desire to take up this possible liability which it is proposed should be brought into operation at the d:screti en of the Delta hoard? The reason why your board agreed to the first proposals for amalgamation was beeause th?y%el:eved the De’ta Linds had in past yea's purchased lands on exceptionally favourable terms—lands which had now become for aajle. Their shareholders had waited ns wero to rank with the original shares. Any increa a of capital certainly alters,the propor¬tion held at the date of the last agreement of the shares then authorised to the existing assets, and it was on thie proportion your board based their consent to the arrangement. Again, is it probable thatnew capital can be emplo yed now by a land company in Egypt, in the face of the prevailing Competition, to the ffame advantage as when the Delta Lands purchased some years ago the Meadi Lands,which ^orm one of their principal assets ? Even if it is probable, do our shareholders desire to increase or double their investments'in Egypt ? The question whether the increase of oapital does or do not materially prejudice the valne of the share! to be given for oar assets is onewhioh yon have to deoide for yourselves and, as our share¬holders include many experienced men «rf basiu'essin Egypt, no doabt an accurate judg¬ment will be given. Although the board are quite prepared, for the reasons before stated, to agree to' amalgamation on fair term", they are in no dernbt as to the success of yonr oompany. The assets are all good, aud are estimated, on a conservative basis, as being worth considerably more than the paid-np oapital, after paying all liabilities. While thes9 matters have been pending between the two companies two instalments of purchase money fjr lands became doe, -on June 30tb and Jaly 1st, and it was provided in the agreement that these should be paid in Egypt by the Delta Lands, they charging interest until it was decided whether the proposed amalgamation was to be approved. If the agreement is confirmed no point arises on this ; but if it is not confirmed the amonUt so disbnrsed will be returned, with the stipulated interest. There are no other liabilities of im¬portance. The half rof the capital of the company which has 'Been called ap has been well employed, and the initial expenses of the oompany were less thin nsaaLfOne of our assets is tho interest of the oompany in the Shorbal Estate, at A’oxaodria. ft is a large bail ling estate, well situated and of ex ceptional and increasing valae, as being almost the only remaining laud available for building purposes within the quadrilateral area which forms Alexandria. The board declined an offer for this proparty, giving a profit of over £30,000 ; bat the company believe that con- si ferfbly largor profits can bo made if this property be olrafnlly realised. The resolutions are now snbmitted to the meeting. Mr. J«- Robertson seconded t-h j resolutions. Mr Wrightson asked if the oh’airman coold give the shareholders an 'approximate valua¬tion of theNQomp iny’s assets.
The Chairman said he estimated the value of the assets, after paying all the liabilities, at £130,0r0 net. Mr. Cadman Jones moved the rejection of the proposals submitted because, in hisopinjor, the Delta Company had not. dealt in good faith. Mr. Wrightson expreatei himsejf in fivoor of the rejection of the agreement. 4? Mr. A. P. Mack said he wishe I, in fairness to the Delta Company, to state that when he WAS in Cairo at the end of May he met one of the directors of that company, who did men¬tion that there was a probability of an increase of capital being made. Mr. Howard asked if the shareholders might Ukalt that the directors as a body did not advise the carrying ont of the amalgamation. Mr. Wrightson said it seemed to him that the assets showed a share valne of 13s. a share, and if they were to be 'given shares on the basis of 6 to Lthey ought to receive an ex¬change of approximately 78s. Grookshauk Pasha said he wished to give a little note of warning to the shareholders. Certain things had arisen in Egypt lately wl/ch had con aid drab’y aHered the state of affairs there, and it was nopafc unlikely that they would see the market very low this winter. The Chairman, replying to Mr,./Howard, said the directors had naturally endeavoured to obtain the opinion of those who were well arquaintod with Egyptian business with regard to the proposed anoalgamation. A member of a firm doing a large business in Cairo, Alex¬andria and London stated that the information from Cairo was that the idea of the Delta C jtupany’s inorease of oapital was not wel¬comed by shareholders, and from Alexandria that the cironlar about the new issae had prodaced a bad impression among shareholders. Taking that view the agreement was one which the directors did not feel justified in pressing on the shareholders. The resolutions were then pat to the meeting, and lost on a show of ban da by 3 votes to 11 Dropsy is Curable By Doan’s BackacheJKidney Pills. Mrs. Mallon Tylqr^of 11. EGYPTIAN delta LAND AND INVESTMENT cO., LTD. AMALGAMATION PROPOSALS PROVISIONALLY AGREED TO. An extraordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Com¬pany Ltd., was held on the 19th July at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, E.C., Sir An k’and ^Colvin, K.C.S.I., K.C.M.G.,-C.I.E. (the Chairman of the company), presiding, f The Secretary (Mr. P. J. Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting, The Chairman said - Yon will doubtle take as read the okonlar sent out by the Board explaining the ohjeots of this meeting. These objects comprise, as yon will have gathered— firstly, the acquisition by this company of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd , atid, secondly; alterations in the memorandum: and articles of association of our company. Owing to a difficulty which has arisen since the issce to yon-of the notice of this meeting in regard to the fusion of this company with the’Egyptian Land and General Toast, Ltd., it will he cotwe nient to pass first to the resolutions which are not affected thereby—namely, Nos 1, 2/3, 4. 5, 6/7, 8 apd 9. It is the case that resolution No. V fur the extension of our sphere of operations, is partly due tp the proposed absorption of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., be¬muse no suoh restrictions as we are bound by SJ imposed upon that company. But we have every reason to believe that there are good opsoings for basiness in the Soudan and parts of Egypt from which we are now excluded by our memorandum and articles of associa¬tion; and though, if the amalgamation referred to be not oarried through, the primary necessity for the alteration disappears, yet this extension of oar sphere , of operations most, before long, come, and the present would appear to be as good an opportunity as any. of dealing with it. Nos 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 8 are desirable alterations owing to the fact that the Delta Light Railways are no longer shareholders, and in oonsequenoa should no longer have control. In regard to No. 9 we regard it as a safe precaution to raise the minimum number of directors required to form a quorum at a Bjard meeting to two. Directors’ Remuneration. I now go back to No. 7 on the subject of the remuneration of the directors. The change in the directors’ fees is,a matter which we wished in any case to put before yon. I must remind yoa that this company was originally regarded as likely to be a small affair, an cffihoot of the railways, and accordingly fees and salaries at¬tached to it were fixed proportionately low. Bat it was farther provided that the directors should receive for division amongst themselves 5 per oent of the profits *in any one year after 5 per oent had been paid to th^shareholders. It is. perhaps as well that oooasion has not yet arisen for such boons to ba claimed. An esti¬mate of the accrued profits may be as safely calculated on. the present market price of oar shares as upon any other basis, and this means that as these profits are realised there will pro¬bably be considerables00*8 for division. What¬ever might be the pecuniary advantages to the Board, they prefer proposing to the share- fhddera that the feei be fixed at what they believe a reasonable and equitable sum, whether as regards the shareh ddera. or directors. 'The fees are at present £IGO to the Chairman and £[() to each direotor, with the prospect of the boons referred to, which it is now proposed that they shoald definitely abandon. In my view, the proposed alterations which I have just enumerated are all desirab’e, whether the amalgamation with the Egyptian Land and General Trm-t, Ltd., is sanctioned oris not. shall be happy to answer any qnestiona in regard to them, so far as it is in my power, And I will proceed to the consideration of the remaining resolutions which depend opon such amalgamation. The general meeting of the Egyptian Land and General Trast. for the con sideratiOn of the fusion of their company with ,ours is fixed for the same time as the one we \re now holding, BO each is at the disadvantage of not knowing the views held or the decision arrived at or likely to be arrived at of the other. The negotiations in connection with the amalgamation commented in E/ypt so far back as February last, when certain diieotors of the two companies met in Egypt 1 need not enter pon the earlier d.ffi mlties connected with these negotiation0, for they do not bear upon the point now at issue ; but it is neciseary foi roe to explaiu a difficulty created by ■Egyptian Land and General Trust since notices of this meeting were sent to you, andwhich may affect the whole position. To thirwd the secretary will read to-yoa the circular issued by the Egyptian Land and GeneraUrrnst, Lttfi, on the 6th July,' and our reply to(a jetterj/o the secretaries covering such circular dated the 9 th idem. The other Company’s Circular. The Secretary then read the following com mwioation-.—“Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., 68 to 74, Palmerston hoaee, 34, Old Broad street, London, EC., 6th July, 1906. Dear Sir (or Madam),—Since the issue of the 4 last oiroqlar to our shareholders, dated 29th Jaue.recommeudirg the amalgamation with the Egyptian Delta Land and' Investment Company, Ltd., it has been ascertained that the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd..- are asking their shareholders at their general ueeting, to be held op the .9th instant, crease their capital from £250,COO to £590,000 in other words, they propose to double their noteal capital. -The effect of this must b6 depredate the market value of the shares which the Egyptian Delta Land and Invest ment Company, Ltd., under the providonal agreement, w ire Ife give in payment for the assets of^ur company, and in fact, the market value of the shares in both compares b.as .5 already considerably depreoiatel. Your .di¬rectors ^ava-Aot bien advised when or at whit price it is contemplated to make the new issue; but it is obvious that the apparent imminence so largo an isxue of new shate^mast prevent he value of tho snares hearing the proport’on which existed at the date of the provisional contraot to> the as-eta of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd., already acquired. The basis on which your Board were originally propat ed to support the arrangement has thus been so materially altered that the Board can nrr longer *t ki the respons bility recommending the confirmation 6f the agreement It is imperative th$t the directors should1 know whether the proxioi already for¬warded in response .to their first circular, or to sent in, are to he need for or against the confirmation of the proposed arrangement. Unless, therefore, you ^propose attending the meeting, will yon plAsse signify to ns your ieh in the course oj post £nd forward your proxy if not already Font.— By order of the Board, Mack and Palmer, Secretaries.’’ The Chairman : A copy of the circular was handed to us, and we wrote as follows-— The Company’s Reply. The Secretary (reading): * 9tl^July, 1906. Messrs. Mack and Palmer, Fecretaries, Egyptian Laud and General Trust, Ltd, 68 to .74, Pal¬merston House, E C. Dear Sirs,—I received with your assistant secretary’s letter of the 6th instant oopies of circular - of the same date addressed to the proprietors of your company reference to the proposed- increase of this company’s capital. My direotors cannot but regret tha*t they were not afforded an oppor¬tunity of eincidating this subject before the issue by your'oompany of a oiroular which may well cause an erroneous impression of their intentions. Iu this company’s oircnlar of the 29th June it was briefly stated thet it was con¬sidered desirable to increase this company’s capital to £*'00,000, but it was at any rate amalgamation, and the advantages or dis-advantages of any such /arrangement as an inorease of capital would he-shared all alike. Thei^nnmerical strength in shares would he as one to six of our present shareholders, and we might have reasouab’y expeoted them Ao feel safe in accepting the deoision of so large a majority, and of feeling assured that the Jhard of this-company would only exercise the powers conferred upon them in so far aif they belisve that the interests of the company and. therefore, of the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., would be ad- vancedlhereby. The Chairman s Pr Lv The position being a Proposal. The position being as escribed to yoa, my proposal to you is that unless the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General TrasMje found to have decided upon the amalgamation at their meeting now being hold, and on the terms arranged,such amalgamation be no longer considered by this oompany. If jfou are pleased to accept thia suggestion, I ask you to authorise me to aot in aocirdance therewith in refer¬ence to resolution No. 11, and I will now refer to the preceding resolution No. 10, wbioh the only one remaining. Had it not been for the proposed amalgamation with the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., we probably shonlduot have asked yoq * so soon to authorise ns to take power to increase our apital, and certainly should not have done so fpr so large an amount. I have explained to yon that no immediate fresh issue of capital is contemplated, and under tbe^Jiresent condi¬tions of doubt as to whether an amalgamation will or will not take place, I propose to post¬pone this question of an inorease to oor capital until our next meetiog. In the event of an amalgamation the same inorease will be pro¬posed to yon as in the resolntion which* we are considering, but otherwise power will be sought to provide for an addition of £100,000 only, in view of possible, though not probable, known to Mr. Mack, one of yoar direotors, agencies in oar present sphere of operations,and that paly power to make snoh inorease was being sought; f2) th* t each increase was to be made as and when and if required ; and (3) that the immediate issue of any part of it was so doubtful that the price of issue had not even been considered. The need for the provision for increasing this company’s capital is created (l)hythefaot that the proposed acquisition of your company’s a9iets will absorb the ba- lame at present available, aud (2) by the proposed extension of its sphere of operation’. The authority now soaght is to provide for this possible want, and it appears to my di-rectors that, if it arises, your shareholders are likely to receivj considerable beuefit from pro rata distribution of new shares, and that as they will only form about one-seventh of the whole they may with confidence accept the decision arrived at bythe larger body—namely, our present shareholders—as to the necessity of making the provision proposed. I may ex plain that whatever inorease be made to this company’s capital yoar shareholders and oars would be equally affeoted in every way. They farther understood from General Hallowes, a direotor of this company, who recently visited Cairo in connection with the fasion of our two companies, that the idea of increasing this company’s capital WAS then mentioned in the presence of Messrs. Mack, Lonsdorfer, Nungo- vich Bey and othe-s. and was received by them-with favour.—Yours faithfully, (Signed} F. J. Horne, Secretary.” The Charman : I will now explain that the propo al for the acquisition of the Egyptian Land and General Trust necessarily, carried wifh it one ter power to increase this company’s capital. Sach acquisition involved thepaymefit to theEgyptian Land and General Trast of 33,3’4 shares, and 4he advance »to them of £55,000 to meet their liabilities at the 30th June lastion certain lands, and would thus more than absorb the balance of our company’s available capital. A a a consequence, and in view, of payments to become doe for properties acquired, and of the proposed extension of the sphere of our operations, we deemed it advisable totakepower to increaseonrcapital to£500,000. Beyond taking this power. I can nnhesitatingly affirm that no programme as to ivsae immediate or otherwise had beeu conridered, and as to any date or price of issue of any of this fresh capita’, 1 can only say that there details have never beeu fixed, and that the circular just read to you ascribes to us intentions which are fir bejond ns. Our intention, as the oiroular dearly expresses it, was simply to take power to issue capital at such futare time as, in oar opinion, might oall for a fresh issue. The power asked for of raising fresh capital and of a pro posal^ to raise fresh- oapital at an early date are absolutely distinct matters. As at present advised we do not propose to make an issne within the next twelve months, and before making any issue we intend to call a meeting of oar shareholders to lay before them the objects for which the issue is proposed, and take their viows as to the cxpendiency of the issue. The biggest issue we have ever made was £100,000, and it would be unreasonable to suppose that we contemplated issuing a quarter of a million, ithir at once or at any one time. 8uoh, how over, seems to have been the opinion created by the oircnlar in question, and on which the di-rectors of that company have withdrawn, as it Feems to os preoipitately, their recommenda¬tion to the Amalgamation of the two companies. Fiom what I have said, it follows that, as and when any fresh istue of our capital was to be made, the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trust would got the benefit of such further issue or issue* equally with our present existing shareholders. The former gentlemen by having acqiffred fehare3 in our company would obtain thb right of subscribing for their proportion, or, bn to other hand, the shares were offered I th the public Ihey would get tin benefityof the proceeds there, The interests of tho /existing shaieholders of our compai y and of those of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., would be tp avail ourselves of opportunities of bosiness in localities from which we have been hitherto exoladed, but which will now be opened to ns. Mr. H. P. Singer asked if the Chairman coold give any information as to the reason why the Delta Light Rai’.ways had oeased to be shareholders in the company. The Chairman replied that as long as the Railway Company were shareho’ders it was difficult for this oompany, with any chanoe of success, to apply to, the Con ft to obtain a modification of the memorandum of assoo:ation necessary to enlarge their sphere of operations. The Railway Company, therefore,' decided, under legal advioe, to dispose of its holding, partly on that account, but also o^the ground that the company bad grown and changed into. much larger oonoern than was originally designed. It was intended originally to parchsse land OD the line of railway in coarse oon- 8traotion and to be oonstraoted, bat the'edm- pany had gone beyond this and the direotors of the railway came to the oonolosion ^hat it was not stfiotly within their powers to be asso-ciated with the Land Company uoder its filter¬ed conditions. div.head: AVIS
div.p:
La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des
Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.

Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être
consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés
exceptés.

Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur
l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.

Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même
jour à 5h.p.m.

L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de
prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier
des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité
Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à
midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: “INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

CROMPTON & Co., LTD. Dynamos, motors and electric machinery of all description.

CHUBB & SON'S LOCK & SAFE CO. LTD Chubb's Steel Safes of all sizes on hand, the building of strong rooms undertaken.
COCHRAN & CO. ANNAN, LTD. The Cochran patent vertical boilers.
THE SEAMLESS STEEL BOAT CO., LTD. Seamless steel boats fitted with any class of motor.
THE COOPER STEAM DIGGER CO. LTD. Diggers made in size No. 5, 6, 8 and 12.
